content:
Got this Clash in Reverse mode.

The first 4 testcases (out of only 5) all have the exact same pattern of four columns, increasing, decreasing, decreasing, increasing, with numbers from 0 to s/2.

Because this pattern has a much simpler logic than "finding all palindromic codes whose sum is a given number", it's almost impossible to guess your logic in Reverse mode with only these 5 testcases.

The following code gets 80% without understanding your logic at all:

s = int(input())
n=s//2
for k in range(n+1):
    print(k,n-k,n-k,k,sep='')

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great work. Loved the clash. 
Can easily be solved in less than 5 minutes, bonus points for satisfying story and the Rocket in the comments.

Here's my solution in Python3:

s = int(input())
res = []
for x in range(100):
    if sum([int(a) for a in str(x)]) == s//2:
        res.append(str(x).zfill(2)+str(x).zfill(2)[::-1])
    
for x in res:
    print(x)

Good challenge.
Worth adding that the output should be in ascending order.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The story is good, the challenge is perfect for a clash ! Nice one :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: i like it
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
this is a good one ngl
This was a fun Clash, difficulty level is just right for a Clash IMO.

Constraints
* Please mention that [[S]] is always an even number.

Cases
* Considering that 0 may be regarded as an edge case but 2 probably isn't, I would suggest to change the input of Validator 2 to either 0 or any other even number not covered by other tests/validators.

Thanks.

Thank you for your feedback! I appreciate your suggestion about highlighting that [[S]] is always an even number. However, I feel that discovering this detail - that only even numbers can produce valid palindromes, could be a valuable "aha!" moment for participants. It’s an insight that adds an extra layer of challenge and learning to the problem.

Regarding the test cases, I have updated it.

Thanks again for your valuable input.
I suggest adding more testcases for which such a simple logic fails!!

Hey, thanks for the feedback. I had a feeling the reverse mode would be tricky. I have added another test case (input = 28). If it is still unclear, I will consider adding the output of an odd input to be an error.

Thank you for your reply and follow-up.

While I agree that discovering that detail is a valuable aha moment, the player won't be able to make that discovery, as they have no access to validators during a clash. The player will also be worried, during a clash, about how they should handle cases where [[S]] is an odd number, as the constraints don't mention that [[S]] will never be an odd number at all.
Thanks for pointing that out. I’ve added the constraint to clarify that [[S]] is always even, to avoid any confusion during the clash.
